member.name: P:SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbookSet.BackgroundCalculation
member.summary: Gets or sets the property which specifies whether interruptible background calculation will be initiated as needed when the last lock on a workbook set is released.

remarks.para: This property is thread safe.
Changing from true to false stops background calculation before the property setter returns.
is on by default. However, background calculation will not be initiated if is set to Calculation.Manual or if a lock is never acquired and subsequently released.
When utilizing background calculation, must be used to acquire a lock before any access to any object in a workbook set.
All Windows Forms components from SpreadsheetGear use GetLock and whenever they access anything in a workbook set.
See and for more information about acquiring and releasing locks as well as the effect this has on background calculation.

member.name: P:SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbookSet.Calculation
member.summary: Gets or sets the property which determines whether this workbook set is automatically calculated as needed.

remarks.para: If is not set to Calculation.Manual, cells containing formulas will always be calculated automatically before values are returned by the SpreadsheetGear for .NET API.
To calculate a workbook set with Calculation set to Calculation.Manual, call .

member.name: P:SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbookSet.CalculateBeforeSave
member.summary: Gets or sets the property which specifies whether workbooks should be calculated as needed before saving.

member.name: P:SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbookSet.CalculationOnDemand
member.summary: Gets or sets the property which determines whether individual cells are calculated on demand. This feature is turned off by default.

remarks.para: Calculation on demand is a feature of SpreadsheetGear which can dramatically increase performance of some applications. There are four primary strategies for calculating cells in SpreadsheetGear:

list.item: Set to Calculation.Manual and call to calculate a workbook set.

Set Calculation to Calculation.Automatic and set to false (the default settings of a workbook set). With these settings, retrieving the value of a formula cell which needs to be calculated will result in the calculation of a logical group of cells all at once. This might be a column of cells, a worksheet, a workbook or the entire workbook set.

Set Calculation to Calculation.Automatic and set CalculationOnDemand to true. With these settings, retrieving the value of a formula cell which needs to be calculated will result in the calculation of only the specified cell and the cells on which it depends.
Mix #2 or #3 with calls to Calculate when it is appropriate.

remarks.para: Suppose you have a workbook where you have 100 rows and three columns. Columns A and B have a number, column C adds A + B. If you will be working within one row at a time, changing numbers in columns A and B, and retrieving the result of the formula in column C, calculation on demand will perform very well.
If, on the other hand, you will be making changes in columns A and B, and retrieving many of the cells in column C, turning off calculation on demand may perform better.
If you know that you will need all cells in a workbook set to be calculated, the most efficient strategy is to call Calculate before you start to retrieve the results of formula cells.
CalculationOnDemand has no effect if automatic calculation is not enabled by setting Calculation to Calculation.Automatic.

member.name: P:SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbookSet.Culture
member.summary: Gets the CultureInfo of this workbook set.

remarks.para: Workbook sets created by the class default to the US English CultureInfo. The Factory class has several methods which allow the CultureInfo to be specified for newly created workbook sets.
The SpreadsheetGear Windows Forms components create workbook sets using the CurrentCulture property of the System.Windows.Forms.Application class.

member.name: P:SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbookSet.CustomLists
member.summary: Gets or sets the custom lists used by IRange.AutoFill and IRange.DataSeries (null by default).

remarks.para: The and methods support built-in lists consisting of long and short day and month names in the culture of the workbook set. These built-in custom lists may not be modified.

In addition, custom lists may be specified for the workbook set with this property. This can be a single list such as an array of strings or it can be a list of lists to specify more than one custom list.

member.value: Returns the currently set custom lists which are null by default.

member.name: P:SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbookSet.DefaultFontSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the font size in points to use in the default font when new workbooks are created.
member.remarks: DefaultFontSize does not affect workbooks which are opened from an existing file or workbooks which already exist in the workbook set.

member.name: P:SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbookSet.Experimental
member.summary: Provides the ability to enable experimental features for this workbook set.

remarks.para: Currently, there is one publicly documented experimental feature in SpreadsheetGear:

list.item: OleDbOpenXmlWorkaround - this experimental feature enables writing of Open XML workbooks which the OleDb provider can read. As of May 2009, the OleDb provider does not fully support the Open XML file format and will not read workbooks written by SpreadsheetGear unless this experimental feature is enabled. At this time it is not clear whether this feature will eventually be removed (because OleDb has been fixed to read compliant Open XML workbooks) or whether this feature might find it's way into a permanent API. Any change to this experimental feature would only be made in a major release of SpreadsheetGear. To enable this experimantal feature, set this property to "OleDbOpenXmlWorkaround".

font.font: Once an experimental feature has been enabled for a workbook set, it cannot be disabled.
Setting this property to an unknown value is ignored.

member.name: P:SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbookSet.MaxRecursions
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum number of recursive calculations allowed when references to cells still needing calculation are detected during workbook set calculation.

remarks.para: Recursion is used when a reference to a cell still needing calculation is detected during workbook set calculation, up to the maximum number of recursions allowed by the MaxRecursions property. When the maximum number of recursions is exceeded, a slower strategy will be employed to calculate these cells.

The default number of recursions allowed is 1024. This is high enough that the vast majority of workbooks will be calculated using recursion, and low enough that stack overflow exceptions are extremely rare (this property was made public two years after SpreadsheetGear was released in response to the first reported case of a stack overflow exception).

Some workbooks will generate stack overflow exceptions in environments with limited stack size available (such as some ASP.NET implementations which are limited to a stack size of 256K). Setting MaxRecursions to a smaller number will limit the amount of stack space used.
Some complex workbooks will calculate faster with higher MaxRecursions settings.
In most cases, the setting of MaxRecursions will have little or no effect after a workbook set is calculated the first time.

member.name: P:SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbookSet.MaxWorksheets
member.summary: Returns the maximum number of worksheets allowed in a workbook.

member.name: P:SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbookSet.NeverRecalc
member.summary: Gets or sets the property which specifies that formulas in this workbook set should never be calculated. This property must be set before any workbook exists in the workbook set.

member.name: P:SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbookSet.ReadObjects
member.summary: Gets or sets the property which specifies whether charts, pictures and drawing objects should be read when reading a workbook.

remarks.para: Charts, pictures and drawing objects are read and written by default. Set this property to false to disable reading of charts, pictures and drawing objects when a workbook is read.
Note that setting ReadDrawingObjects to false will not disable reading of chart sheets.

example.code:
Imports System Imports SpreadsheetGear
Namespace ConsoleApplication _ ' Demonstrate reading a workbook without VBA or objects (shapes). Class Program
Public Overloads Shared Sub Main() ' Create a new empty workbook. Dim workbookSet As IWorkbookSet = Factory.GetWorkbookSet()
' Set to not read VBA or Objects (shapes). workbookSet.ReadVBA = False workbookSet.ReadObjects = False
' Read MyWorkbook.xls without VBA or objects. Dim workbook As IWorkbook = workbookSet.Workbooks.Open("MyWorkbook.xls") End Sub 'Main End Class 'Program End Namespace 'ConsoleApplication

member.name: P:SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbookSet.ReadVBA
member.summary: Gets or sets the property which specifies whether VBA Macros should be read when reading a workbook.

remarks.para: VBA Macros are read and written by default. Set this property to false to disable reading of VBA Macros when a workbook is read.

Note that support for VBA Macros is limited to reading and writing the OLE Compound Document streams. VBA Macros cannot be copied, modified or deleted, and are not updated when worksheets or other objects are copied, modified or deleted.

example.code:
Imports System Imports SpreadsheetGear
Namespace ConsoleApplication _ ' Demonstrate reading a workbook without VBA or objects (shapes). Class Program
Public Overloads Shared Sub Main() ' Create a new empty workbook. Dim workbookSet As IWorkbookSet = Factory.GetWorkbookSet()
' Set to not read VBA or Objects (shapes). workbookSet.ReadVBA = False workbookSet.ReadObjects = False
' Read MyWorkbook.xls without VBA or objects. Dim workbook As IWorkbook = workbookSet.Workbooks.Open("MyWorkbook.xls") End Sub 'Main End Class 'Program End Namespace 'ConsoleApplication

member.name: E:SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbookSet.EndCalculate
member.summary: Occurs when calculation of this workbook set has completed. See remarks for information about the calling thread.

remarks.para: This event occurs when calculation of this workbook set has completed.
This event is always invoked on the thread which completes calculation of the workbook set:

list.item: If calculation completes during execution of an API such as which may require calculation to be completed, the locked state of the workbook set will be the same as when the API was called.
If calculation completes during background calculation, the invoking thread is the background calculation thread and the workbook set will be locked before this event is invoked.

remarks.para: This event will not occur until calculation is complete. For example, this event will not occur if a partial calculation is completed in response to getting the value of a cell, and it will not be invoked if background calculation is interrupted.
The WorkbookView.Calculate event is always invoked on the thread which created the WorkbookView control and is generally a better choice when using the WorkbookView control.

member.name: T:SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbooks
member.summary: Represents all of the workbooks in a workbook set.

example.code: Class Program Shared Sub Main() ' Create a new empty workbook set. Dim workbookSet As SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbookSet = SpreadsheetGear.Factory.GetWorkbookSet() ' Create a new empty workbook in the workbook set. Dim workbook As SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbook = workbookSet.Workbooks.Add() ' Save to C:\MyData.xls as an Excel file. workbook.SaveAs("C:\\MyData.xls", SpreadsheetGear.FileFormat.XLS97) ' Set Sheet1!A1 to "Hello World!". workbook.Worksheets("Sheet1").Cells("A1").Value = "Hello World!" ' Save to C:\MyData.xls again. workbook.Save() ' Close the workbook, removing it from the workbook set. workbookSet.Workbooks.Close() ' Open the saved workbook from memory. workbook = workbookSet.Workbooks.Open("C:\\MyData.xls") ' Output Sheet1!A1. System.Console.WriteLine(workbook.Worksheets("Sheet1").Cells("A1").Value.ToString()) End Sub 'Main End Class 'Program

member.name: M:SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbooks.Add
member.summary: Returns a newly created workbook.
member.returns: The newly created workbook.
member.remarks: The number of worksheets in the new workbook is specified by IWorkbookSet.SheetsInNewWorkbook.

example.code: Class Program Shared Sub Main() ' Create a new empty workbook set. Dim workbook As SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbook = workbookSet.Workbooks.Add() ' Set Sheet1!A1 to "Hello World!". workbook.Worksheets("Sheet1").Cells("A1").Value = "Hello World!" ' Save to memory as an Excel file. Dim buffer As Byte() = workbook.SaveToMemory(SpreadsheetGear.FileFormat.XLS97) ' Close the workbook, removing it from the workbook set. workbook.Close() ' Open the saved workbook from memory. workbook = workbookSet.Workbooks.OpenFromMemory(buffer) ' Output Sheet1!A1. System.Console.WriteLine(workbook.Worksheets("Sheet1").Cells("A1").Value.ToString()) End Sub 'Main End Class 'Program

member.name: M:SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbooks.OpenFromStream(System.IO.Stream)
member.summary: Open an existing workbook in a newly created instance of IWorkbook.
member.returns: The opened workbook.

remarks.para: The stream must consist solely of a file which SpreadsheetGear is able to read. If the stream is not seekable, this method will copy the stream to a MemoryStream and read the workbook from the MemoryStream.
The various workbook settings which make a workbook read-only in an end user workbookSet have no affect at this level. These settings are available as IWorkbook properties.

example.code:
Module Program Sub Main() ' Create a simple workbook. Dim workbook As SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbook = SpreadsheetGear.Factory.GetWorkbook() workbook.Worksheets("Sheet1").Cells("A1").Value = "Hello World!"
' Save the workbook to a memory stream. Dim memoryStream As New System.IO.MemoryStream() workbook.SaveToStream(memoryStream, SpreadsheetGear.FileFormat.OpenXMLWorkbook)
' Close the workbook. workbook.Close()
' Create another workbook from the memory stream. workbook = SpreadsheetGear.Factory.GetWorkbookSet().Workbooks.OpenFromStream(memoryStream) Console.WriteLine("Sheet1!A1='{0}'", workbook.Worksheets("Sheet1").Cells("A1").Value) End Sub End Module

member.param: The stream containing the workbook to open.

member.summary: Returns a newly created data set consisting of a data table for each of the ranges specified by reference.
member.returns: the newly created data set.

remarks.para: Each reference must consist of a defined name or a range reference such as:

list.item: "A1:E15" - specifies the range A1:E15 in the first worksheet.
"Sheet3!B2:D5" - specifies the range B2:D5 in Sheet3.
"MyDatabase" - specifies the worksheet and range referred to by the defined name "MyDatabase".
"A1:E15,Sheet3!B2:D5,MyDatabase" - specifies all of the above as three data tables in the data set.

member.param: a comma separated list of ranges.
Specifies optional features such as column headers and formatted text values.

member.name: M:SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbook.NumberToDateTime(System.Double)
member.summary: Converts the specified date-time serial number to an instance of System.DateTime.
member.param: The date-time serial number to convert.
member.returns: An instance of System.DateTime initialized with the converted date-time serial number.
member.remarks: Dates and times are stored in worksheet cells as a date-time serial number.

member.name: M:SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbook.Save
member.summary: Saves this workbook using the current FullName.
member.remarks: The various workbook settings which make a workbook read-only in an end user workbookSet have no affect at this level.

example.code: Class Program Shared Sub Main() ' Create a new empty workbook set. Dim workbookSet As SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbookSet = SpreadsheetGear.Factory.GetWorkbookSet() ' Create a new empty workbook in the workbook set. Dim workbook As SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbook = workbookSet.Workbooks.Add() ' Save to C:\MyData.xls as an Excel file. workbook.SaveAs("C:\\MyData.xls", SpreadsheetGear.FileFormat.XLS97) ' Set Sheet1!A1 to "Hello World!". workbook.Worksheets("Sheet1").Cells("A1").Value = "Hello World!" ' Save to C:\MyData.xls again. workbook.Save() ' Close the workbook, removing it from the workbook set. workbookSet.Workbooks.Close() ' Open the saved workbook from memory. workbook = workbookSet.Workbooks.Open("C:\\MyData.xls") ' Output Sheet1!A1. System.Console.WriteLine(workbook.Worksheets("Sheet1").Cells("A1").Value.ToString()) End Sub 'Main End Class 'Program

member.name: M:SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbook.SaveAs(System.String,SpreadsheetGear.FileFormat)
member.summary: Saves this workbook using the specified filename and FileFormat, and updates the FullName property.
member.remarks: Note that the various workbook settings which make a workbook read-only in an end user workbookSet have no affect at this level.

example.code: Module Program Sub Main() ' Create a new empty workbook in a new workbook set. Dim workbook As SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbook = SpreadsheetGear.Factory.GetWorkbook() ' Set Sheet1!A1 to "Hello World!". workbook.Worksheets("Sheet1").Cells("A1").Value = "Hello World!" ' Save to C:\MyData.xls as Excel file. workbook.SaveAs("C:\\MyData.xls", SpreadsheetGear.FileFormat.XLS97) ' Open C:\MyData.xls. workbook = SpreadsheetGear.Factory.GetWorkbook("C:\\MyData.xls") ' Output Sheet1!A1. System.Console.WriteLine(workbook.Worksheets("Sheet1").Cells("A1").Value.ToString()) End Sub End Module

member.name: M:SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbook.SaveToMemory(SpreadsheetGear.FileFormat)
member.summary: Saves this workbook to a newly created memory buffer in the specified FileFormat.
member.returns: The memory buffer with the saved workbook.
member.remarks: Note that the various workbook settings which make a workbook read-only in an end user workbookSet have no affect at this level.

example.code: Class Program Shared Sub Main() ' Create a new empty workbook set. Dim workbookSet As SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbookSet = SpreadsheetGear.Factory.GetWorkbookSet() ' Create a new empty workbook in the workbook set. Dim workbook As SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbook = workbookSet.Workbooks.Add() ' Set Sheet1!A1 to "Hello World!". workbook.Worksheets("Sheet1").Cells("A1").Value = "Hello World!" ' Save to memory as an Excel file. Dim buffer As Byte() = workbook.SaveToMemory(SpreadsheetGear.FileFormat.XLS97) ' Close the workbook, removing it from the workbook set. workbook.Close() ' Open the saved workbook from memory. workbook = workbookSet.Workbooks.OpenFromMemory(buffer) ' Output Sheet1!A1. System.Console.WriteLine(workbook.Worksheets("Sheet1").Cells("A1").Value.ToString()) End Sub 'Main End Class 'Program

member.name: M:SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbook.SaveToStream(System.IO.Stream,SpreadsheetGear.FileFormat)
member.summary: Saves this workbook to a stream in the specified FileFormat.
member.param: The stream to write the workbook to.
The file format to save the workbook in.

remarks.para: Note that the various workbook settings which make a workbook read-only in an end user workbookSet have no affect at this level.

example.code:
Module Program Sub Main() ' Create a simple workbook. Dim workbook As SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbook = SpreadsheetGear.Factory.GetWorkbook() workbook.Worksheets("Sheet1").Cells("A1").Value = "Hello World!"
' Save the workbook to a memory stream. Dim memoryStream As New System.IO.MemoryStream() workbook.SaveToStream(memoryStream, SpreadsheetGear.FileFormat.OpenXMLWorkbook)
' Close the workbook. workbook.Close()
' Create another workbook from the memory stream. workbook = SpreadsheetGear.Factory.GetWorkbookSet().Workbooks.OpenFromStream(memoryStream) Console.WriteLine("Sheet1!A1='{0}'", workbook.Worksheets("Sheet1").Cells("A1").Value) End Sub End Module

member.name: P:SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbook.Colors

member.name: P:SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbook.Date1904
member.summary: Returns true if dates are represented as the number of days since 1/1/1904, false if dates are represented as the number of days since 12/31/1899.
member.remarks: The default value is false. Note that, for historical reasons, 1900 is incorrectly considered to be a leap year.

member.name: P:SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbook.DisplayDrawingObjects
member.summary: Gets or sets the option which specifies how drawing objects are to be displayed.

member.name: P:SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbook.FileFormat
member.summary: Returns the file format which the workbook was last opened from or saved to. If the workbook has never been saved, the default file format is returned.

member.name: P:SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbook.FullName
member.summary: Gets or sets the full name (including the path) of the workbook.

member.name: P:SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbook.IsModified
member.summary: Gets or sets the property which specifies whether the workbook has been modified since it was created, opened or saved.

remarks.para: When a workbook is modified this property will be set to true. Calling , or resets this property back to false.
The default behavior of this property can be overridden by setting or resetting it at any time.

member.name: P:SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbook.Name
member.summary: Returns the name (excluding the path) of the workbook.

member.name: P:SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbook.Names
member.summary: Returns the collection of defined names in this workbook.

member.name: P:SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbook.PrecisionAsDisplayed
member.summary: Gets or sets the property which determines whether numbers will be rounded to the precision of the number format.
member.remarks: When PrecisionAsDisplayed is changed from false to true, all numbers in the workbook are rounded according to their number format. Setting PrecisionAsDisplayed back to false does not bring back the original values of these numbers.

member.name: P:SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbook.ProtectStructure
member.summary: Gets or sets the property which determines whether the structure (number and order of worksheets) of a workbook may be changed.

member.name: P:SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbook.ProtectWindows
member.summary: Gets or sets the property which determines whether the windows of a workbook are protected from changes.

member.name: P:SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbook.ReadOnlyRecommended
member.summary: Gets or sets the property which determines whether read-only mode will be recommended to the user when the workbook is opened.

member.name: P:SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbook.SaveLinkValues
member.summary: Gets or sets the property which determines whether externally referenced values will be saved with the workbook, enabling cells which refer to those values to be calculated without returning a #REF! error.

member.name: P:SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbook.Sheets
member.summary: Returns an instance of ISheets which provides access to all sheets in this workbook.
member.remarks: For easier access to just the IWorksheet's in a workbook, use IWorkbook.Worksheets.

member.name: P:SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbook.Styles

member.name: P:SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbook.UpdateLinks
member.summary: Gets or sets the property which determines whether externally referenced values will be updated when a workbook is loaded by Excel. SpreadsheetGear supports reading, writing and modifying this value, but does not support automatically updating links unless the workbook is loaded into the same workbook set.

member.name: T:SpreadsheetGear.IColors
member.summary: Represents the color palette of a workbook.

remarks.para: Text and object colors are stored internally as indexes into a palette. Every workbook is created with a default color palette. Use the IColors interface to query the color palette or to modify it.

Most objects provide the option of specifying a color as an index into this color palette or as an instance of SpreadsheetGear.Drawing.Color, in which case the actual color to be used will be the color in the palette which is closest to the specified SpreadsheetGear.Drawing.Color.
Workbooks with a custom color palette are saved with the custom palette.

members.member:
Gets or sets the color at the specified zero based index.
The zero based index of the color to get or set. #

member.name: P:SpreadsheetGear.IColors.Count
member.summary: Returns the number of colors in the color palette.

member.name: T:SpreadsheetGear.IWorksheets
member.summary: Represents a collection of worksheets in a workbook.
member.remarks: Only normal worksheets are included in this collection. Chart sheets, dialog sheets, Visual Basic modules and Excel 4 Macro Sheets are excluded.

example.code: Class Program Shared Sub Main() ' Create a new empty workbook set. Dim workbookSet As SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbookSet = SpreadsheetGear.Factory.GetWorkbookSet() ' Create a new empty workbook in the workbook set. Dim workbook As SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbook = workbookSet.Workbooks.Add() ' Add a second worksheet. workbook.Worksheets.Add() ' Rename worksheet "Sheet1" to "Hello" workbook.Worksheets("Sheet1").Name = "Hello" ' Rename worksheet "Sheet2" to "World" workbook.Worksheets("Sheet2").Name = "World" ' Save to C:\MyData.xls. workbook.SaveAs("C:\MyData.xls", SpreadsheetGear.FileFormat.XLS97) ' Close the workbook, removing it from the workbook set. workbookSet.Workbooks.Close() ' Open the saved workbook from memory. workbook = workbookSet.Workbooks.Open("C:\MyData.xls") ' Output the sheet names separated by a space ("Hello World"). System.Console.WriteLine((workbook.Worksheets(0).Name + " " + workbook.Worksheets(1).Name)) End Sub 'Main End Class 'Program

member.name: T:SpreadsheetGear.Windows.Forms.WorkbookView
member.summary:
Provides a fully functional spreadsheet control which supports rich functionality including familiar keyboard and mouse selections, in-cell editing, a FormulaBar control, goto, cut, copy, paste, clear, undo, redo, printing, interruptible background calculation, real time workbook updates, multiple workbooks,
DisplayReference, WorkbookDesigner, WorkbookExplorer, RangeExplorerChartExplorerShapeExplorer and more.

remarks.para: The control adheres to the standard Windows Forms threading model. Accessing any members of a must be done from the thread which created the .
For important information about the threading model of SpreadsheetGear see and .

To modify the workbook(s) associated with a at design time, right click on the and select Workbook Designer. From the Workbook Designer, you can open, edit, format, save and close workbooks. The workbooks which are left open in the Workbook Designer when the designer is closed will be saved with the form containing the , and will be loaded into the workbook set associated with the when the form is created at run time.
The , , , and properties are the most commonly used workbook view properties.

Use the and properties to control which workbook or which worksheet ranges are displayed in the workbook view. The DisplayReference property provides the ability to display multiple workbooks in a single workbook view control, as well as the ability to limit what the user of the workbook view control is able to see.
The , and events are the most commonly used workbook view events.

member.summary: Ends edit mode and commits any changes.

member.name: M:SpreadsheetGear.Windows.Forms.WorkbookView.BeginUpdate
member.summary: Interrupts background calculation if necessary, acquires an exclusive lock on the workbook set associated with this , and suspends painting and events until is called.

remarks.para: The control adheres to the standard Windows Forms threading model. Calls to this method must be made from the thread which created the WorkbookView.
See for more information.

member.name: M:SpreadsheetGear.Windows.Forms.WorkbookView.EndUpdate
member.summary: Restores painting and events to the state they were in before the last call to , releases the lock acquired by BeginUpdate, and starts background calculation if appropriate.

remarks.para: The control adheres to the standard Windows Forms threading model. Calls to this method must be made from the thread which created the WorkbookView.
See for more information.

member.name: M:SpreadsheetGear.Windows.Forms.WorkbookView.CheckLayoutDisplay
member.summary: Checks to see that WorkbookViewTab's are laid out correctly when either default or custom tabs are being used. If default tabs are being used and we do not have a current workbook, we use the first workbook we can find in the WorkbookSet, but only if DisplaySupported is true. The WorkbookDesigner turns this property off so we don't use another workbook after closing.

Gets or sets the property which specifies whether background calculation is enabled for the workbook set.
See , , and for more information.

member.name: P:SpreadsheetGear.Windows.Forms.WorkbookView.DisplayReference
member.summary: Gets or sets the property which specifies which workbook or set of cell ranges to display in the workbook view.

remarks.para: Use the DisplayReference property to specify what should be displayed for each "sheet tab" of the workbook view control.

takes a comma separated list of formulas which must return a range. These formulas are evaluated each time a calculation completes in the workbook set associated with the workbook view control, by calling the method of the first worksheet of the first workbook of the workbook set.
Examples of valid settings for DisplayReference include:

list.item: "" displays the first workbook of the workbook set.
"A1:C3" displays the range A1:C3 from the first worksheet of the first workbook.

"[Book1]Sheet1!A1:C3, Book2!MyName" displays the range A1:C3 from the worksheet "Sheet1" of the workbook "Book1" on the first "sheet tab", and displays the range referred to by the defined name "MyName" of workbook "Book2" on the second sheet tab.
"INDIRECT([Book1]Sheet1!A1)" displays the range referred to by the text in the cell A1 of the worksheet "Sheet1" of the workbook "Book1".

remarks.para: Use the property to specify the text to display on each "sheet tab".

summary.para: Gets or sets the property which specifies the text to display on each of the "sheet tabs" of the workbook view.

remarks.para: Use the property in conjunction with the property to specify the text to display on the "sheet tabs" of the workbook view control.
The names are specified as a comma separated list of formulas which return the text to display. Some valid examples include:

list.item: "\"MySheet1\", \"MySheet2\"" displays "MySheet1" on the first sheet tab and "MySheet2" on the second sheet tab.
"[Book1]Sheet1!A1" displays the text in the cell A1 on the first sheet tab.

member.summary: Occurs sometime after calculation of the workbook set associated with the workbook view control has completed.

member.name: E:SpreadsheetGear.Windows.Forms.WorkbookView.CellBeginEdit
member.summary: Occurs when edit mode is being initiated.

remarks.para: The event occurs when edit mode is being initiated, and provides the event handler with the ability to modify the text to be edited or cancel edit mode.
The event is always invoked on the thread which created the workbook view control, and a lock is always acquired on the workbook set associated with the workbook view control before is invoked.

member.name: E:SpreadsheetGear.Windows.Forms.WorkbookView.CellCancelEdit
member.summary: Occurs when edit mode is being canceled and provides the ability to force edit mode to continue by cancelling the event.

remarks.para: The event occurs when edit mode is being canceled, and provides the event handler with the ability to force edit mode to continue.
The event is always invoked on the thread which created the workbook view control, and a lock is always acquired on the workbook set associated with the workbook view control before is invoked.

member.name: E:SpreadsheetGear.Windows.Forms.WorkbookView.CellEndEdit
member.summary: Occurs when edit mode is ending and provides the ability to force edit mode to continue by cancelling the event.

remarks.para: The event occurs when edit mode is being ended, and provides the event handler with the ability to modify the text to be placed into the , or force edit mode to continue.
The event is always invoked on the thread which created the workbook view control, and a lock is always acquired on the workbook set associated with the workbook view control before is invoked.

member.name: E:SpreadsheetGear.Windows.Forms.WorkbookView.RangeChanged
member.summary: Occurs sometime after an property setter or method changes one or more of the cells in the range.

remarks.para: It is important to note that some actions, such as insert or delete, will change cells outside of the range, and possibly even modify formulas in other worksheets or workbooks.
The event is always invoked on the thread which created the workbook view control, and a lock is always acquired on the workbook set associated with the workbook view control before is invoked.

member.name: E:SpreadsheetGear.Windows.Forms.WorkbookView.RangeSelectionChanged
member.summary: Occurs after the range selection changes.

remarks.para: This event also occurs when the active tab is changed.
The event is always invoked on the thread which created the workbook view control, and a lock is always acquired on the workbook set associated with the workbook view control before is invoked.

member.name: E:SpreadsheetGear.Windows.Forms.WorkbookView.RangeSelectionChanging

remarks.para: This event does not occur when the active tab is about to change.

member.name: T:SpreadsheetGear.ColorIndex
member.summary: ColorIndex provides special constants which specify that a color should be Automatic or None (transparent).
member.remarks: Colors may be specified as indexes into a color palette. ColorIndex.Automatic and ColorIndex.None are special values which may be supplied in place of a normal color index.

member.name: F:SpreadsheetGear.ColorIndex.Automatic
member.summary: Specifies that the color is determined automatically.
member.remarks: In most cases the automatic color for text or an object is obtained from the current system colors. Typically this is the default window text color for text and lines or the default window color to fill a background.

member.name: F:SpreadsheetGear.ColorIndex.None
member.summary: Specifies no color (transparent).
member.remarks: Setting the color of an object to None will cause the object to be transparent.

member.name: M:SpreadsheetGear.Windows.Forms.UIManager.CreateCustomControl(SpreadsheetGear.Shapes.IShape)
member.summary: Returns the Control to use in place of the specified autoshape or null if the default autoshape should be used.
member.param: Specifies the shape in question; check the ID or Name property to distinguish one shape from another.

remarks.para: Override this method to provide a custom control replacement for an autoshape. Worksheet form controls such as checkboxes cannot be replaced.
The control will be disposed of as soon as it is scrolled out of view and CreateCustomControl will be called again if it is scrolled back into view.

member.summary: Specifies that column width, hidden state and outline info be preserved.

member.name: T:SpreadsheetGear.Data.SetDataFlags
member.summary: Specifies options for the method.

member.name: F:SpreadsheetGear.Data.SetDataFlags.None
member.summary: Specifies default behaviour: automatically determine the best cell type and formatting; first row does receive column headers; do not insert cells to open space for the DataTable.

member.name: F:SpreadsheetGear.Data.SetDataFlags.AllText
member.summary: All values are stored and formatted as text, including numeric and boolean types which are converted to text.

member.name: F:SpreadsheetGear.Data.SetDataFlags.NoColumnHeaders
member.summary: Specifies that a row with column headers will not be created from the DataTable's column names.

member.name: F:SpreadsheetGear.Data.SetDataFlags.InsertCells
member.summary: Specifies that cells should be inserted to make room for the DataTable.

member.name: F:SpreadsheetGear.Data.SetDataFlags.WrapNoColumnHeaders
member.summary: Specifies that a row with column headers will not be created from the DataTable's column names when data wraps to a new worksheet.

member.name: F:SpreadsheetGear.Data.SetDataFlags.WrapToNewWorksheet
member.summary: Specifies that data will wrap to a new worksheet if it does not fit on the current worksheet; column headers will be placed at the top of this new worksheet unless SetDataFlags.WrapNoColumnHeaders is specified.

member.name: F:SpreadsheetGear.Data.SetDataFlags.WrapToNewWorksheet64K
member.summary: Specifies that data will wrap to a new worksheet if it does not fit in the first 65536 rows of the current worksheet; column headers will be placed at the top of this new worksheet unless SetDataFlags.WrapNoColumnHeaders is specified.

member.name: T:SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.Function
member.summary: Override this class to implement a SpreadsheetGear custom function.

remarks.para: must not use any API involving the workbook set containing the instance of the custom function being evaluated. However, custom functions may use one or more separate workbook sets without limitation.
Create a default custom function by specifying "*" as the name parameter to . Use to retrieve the name of the function being evaluated.

example.code:
Class Program ' Demonstrate the use of custom functions in SpreadsheetGear. Shared Sub Main() ' Create a new empty workbook. Dim workbook As SpreadsheetGear.IWorkbook = SpreadsheetGear.Factory.GetWorkbook() ' Add the custom functions to the workbook set. workbook.WorkbookSet.Add(MyAdd.MyAddSingleton) workbook.WorkbookSet.Add(MySum.MySumSingleton) ' Get Sheet1 and its cells. Dim sheet1 As SpreadsheetGear.IWorksheet = workbook.Worksheets(0) Dim cells As SpreadsheetGear.IRange = sheet1.Cells ' Assign values and formulas to cells. cells("A1").Value = 1.1 cells("B1").Value = 1.2 cells("C1").Formula = "=MYADD(A1,B1)" cells("A2").Value = 2.1 cells("B2").Value = 2.2 cells("C2").Formula = "=MYADD(A2,B2)" cells("C3").Formula = "=MYSUM(C1:C2)" ' Output the result of the custom functions. System.Console.WriteLine("1.1+1.2+2.1+2.2={0}", cells("C3").Text) End Sub 'Main
' A simple addition custom function. Public Class MyAdd Inherits SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.Function ' Set to the one and only instance of MyAdd. Public Shared MyAddSingleton As New MyAdd ' Add two numbers. Public Overrides Sub Evaluate(ByVal arguments As SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.IArguments, ByVal result As SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.IValue) ' Verify that there are two arguments. If arguments.Count = 2 Then ' Get the two arguments as numbers, and add them. result.Number = arguments.GetNumber(0) + arguments.GetNumber(1) Else ' Return ValueError.Value. result.Error = SpreadsheetGear.ValueError.Value End If End Sub 'Evaluate
' Singleton class - so make the constructor private. Private Sub New() ' The name of the custom function. MyBase.New("MYADD", SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.Volatility.Invariant, SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.ValueType.Number) End Sub 'New End Class 'MyAdd
' A custom function which sums any number of simple or complex values. Public Class MySum Inherits SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.Function ' Set to the one and only instance of MySum. Public Shared MySumSingleton As New MySum
' Sums any number of values or ranges. Public Overrides Sub Evaluate(ByVal arguments As SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.IArguments, ByVal result As SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.IValue) ' Initialize the sum to 0. Dim sum As Double = 0.0 ' for each argument. Dim i As Integer For i = 0 To arguments.Count - 1 Dim rows As Integer Dim cols As Integer ' Get the dimensions (returns 1x1 for simple values). arguments.GetArrayDimensions(i, rows, cols) ' for each row. Dim row As Integer For row = 0 To rows - 1 ' for each column. Dim col As Integer For col = 0 To cols - 1 ' Get the value. Dim val As SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.IValue = arguments.GetArrayValue(i, row, col) ' Is it a number? If val.IsNumber Then ' Add it to the sum. sum += val.Number ' Is it an error? Else If val.IsError Then ' Return an error immediately. result.Error = val.Error Return End If End If Next col Next row Next i ' Return the sum. result.Number = sum End Sub 'Evaluate
' Singleton class - so make the constructor private. Private Sub New() ' The name of the custom function. MyBase.New("MYSUM", SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.Volatility.Invariant, SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.ValueType.Number) End Sub End Class 'MySum End Class 'Program

member.name: M:SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.Function.#ctor(System.String,SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.Volatility,SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.ValueType)
member.summary: Initializes an instance of a custom function.

remarks.para: is converted to upper case before storing.
Create a default custom function by specifying "*" for . This default custom function will be used for any function which is undefined.

member.param: The name of the custom function or "*" to specify the default custom function.
The volatility of the function.
Specifies the return type for the custom function, or ValueType.Variant for a variable return type.

member.name: M:SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.Function.Evaluate(SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.IArguments,SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.IValue)
member.summary: Evaluates a custom function with the specified arguments. See the remarks in the help for this method for a number of rules which must be taken into account.

remarks.para: The implementation of this method must follow a number of rules:

list.item: The method must be thread safe. Future versions of SpreadsheetGear may call this method from multiple threads at the same time.

The method must not use any API in the workbook set which is being calculated except for IArguments.CurrentWorksheet.Name, IArguments.CurrentWorksheet.Index or IArguments.CurrentWorksheet.Workbook.Name.
All access to cells must be through arguments.

Accessing the IArguments indexer has the side effect of converting references to ranges or arrays to a single simple value. Use and to access the individual values of a range or array. For example, if the first custom function argument is the range A1:C3, setting a watch on arguments[0] in a debugger will convert this range to a single simple value.
No references to interfaces or objects passed to, or acquired during the execution of this method should be used after this method completes execution.

remarks.para: If an exception is thrown during custom function evaluation, the custom function will return ValueError.Name.

member.param: Provides access to the arguments to this custom function. Note that using the IArguments indexer has the side effect of converting a range reference or array to a simple value (use GetArrayDimensions and GetArrayValue to get individual values from a range or array).
Assign the result of the custom function to result. The value of result is undefined until set by the Evaluate method.

member.name: P:SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.Function.ReturnType
member.summary: Indicates the return type of the custom function.
member.remarks: A return type of ValueType.Variant specifies that the return type is variable.

summary.para: Indicates the volatility of the custom function.

member.name: P:SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.Function.Name
member.summary: Returns the name of the custom function.

member.name: T:SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.IArguments
member.summary: Represents the arguments of a custom function to the Function.Evaluate() method.

member.name: M:SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.IArguments.ClearError
member.summary: Clears errors associated with the custom function which is currently being evaluated.

remarks.para: Typically, the first error seen in any argument to a custom function will be the result of the custom function. To override this behavior, call after finishing all access to function arguments.
Note: Accessing function arguments after calling will result in undefined behavior.
The recommended practice for overriding default error handling is to:

member.name: M:SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.IArguments.GetArrayDimensions(System.Int32,System.Int32@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Returns the dimensions, consisting of the number of rows and columns, of the specified argument.
member.remarks: This method returns the dimensions of ranges and arrays. For simple values, one is returned for rows and columns.

example.code:
Imports System Imports SpreadsheetGear
Namespace ConsoleApplication _ '/ <summary> '/ Demonstrate a custom function which sums the range of cells or values passed to it. '/ </summary> Class Program
'Entry point which delegates to C-style main Private Function Public Overloads Shared Sub Main() ' Create a new empty workbook. Dim workbookSet As IWorkbookSet = Factory.GetWorkbookSet()
' Add the custom function to the workbook set. workbookSet.Add(MySum.MySumSingleton)
' Add a workbook to the workbook set. Dim workbook As IWorkbook = workbookSet.Workbooks.Add()
' Get the first sheet and it's cells Dim worksheet As SpreadsheetGear.IWorksheet = workbook.Worksheets(0) Dim cells As SpreadsheetGear.IRange = worksheet.Cells
' Assign values and formulas to cells. cells("A1").Value = 1 ' The OFFSET(...) function enables creation of a range equal to ' the number of rows which have values in column A and one column. cells("B1").Formula = "=MYSUM(OFFSET(A1,0,0,COUNT(A:A),1))"
Console.WriteLine(("Result calculated from MYSUM = " + cells("B1").Text + " (should be 1)."))
' Add another value to column A. cells("A2").Value = 2
Console.WriteLine(("Result calculated from MYSUM = " + cells("B1").Text + " (should be 3).")) End Sub 'Main End Class 'Program _
' A simple SUM custom function. Public Class MySum Inherits SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.Function ' Set to the one and only instance of MySum. Public Shared MySumSingleton As New MySum()
' Sum the numbers in a range or array. Public Overrides Sub Evaluate(ByVal arguments As SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.IArguments, ByVal result As SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.IValue) ' Verify that there are two arguments. If arguments.Count = 1 Then Dim rowCount As Integer Dim colCount As Integer arguments.GetArrayDimensions(0, rowCount, colCount) Dim numbers(rowCount, colCount) As Double Dim row As Integer For row = 0 To rowCount - 1 Dim col As Integer For col = 0 To colCount - 1 Dim value As SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.IValue = arguments.GetArrayValue(0, row, col) If value.Type = SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.ValueType.Number Then numbers(row, col) = value.Number End If Next col Next row ' Get the two arguments as numbers, and sum them. result.Number = SumThem(numbers) ' Return ValueError.Value. Else result.Error = SpreadsheetGear.ValueError.Value End If End Sub 'Evaluate
Private Function SumThem(ByVal numbers(,) As Double) As Double Dim sum As Double = 0.0 Dim rowCount As Integer = numbers.GetUpperBound(0) + 1 Dim colCount As Integer = numbers.GetUpperBound(1) + 1 Dim row As Integer For row = 0 To rowCount - 1 Dim col As Integer For col = 0 To colCount - 1 sum += numbers(row, col) Next col Next row Return sum End Function 'SumThem
' Singleton class - so make the constructor private. Private Sub New() ' The name of the custom function. MyBase.New("MYSUM", SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.Volatility.Invariant, SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.ValueType.Number) End Sub 'New ' For a given set of inputs, this function always returns the same value. End Class 'MySum End Namespace 'ConsoleApplication ' This function returns a number.

member.param: Specifies the zero based index of the argument.
Set to the number of rows in the specified argument, or one for a simple argument.
Set to the number columns in the specified argument, or one for a simple argument.

member.name: M:SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.IArguments.GetArrayFormulaInfo(System.Int32@,System.Int32@,System.Int32@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Returns true and sets row1, col1, row2 and col2 to the zero based upper-left and lower-right row and column indexes of the array formula if the formula currently being evaluated is an array formula, or returns false and leaves the parameters unchanged if the formula currently being evaluated is not an array formula.
member.returns: true if the formula currently being evaluated is an array formula, or false if the formula currently being evaluated is not an array formula.
member.param: Will be set to the zero based upper row of the array formula currently being evaluated, or left unchanged if the formula currently being evaluated is not an array formula.
Will be set to the zero based left column of the array formula currently being evaluated, or left unchanged if the formula currently being evaluated is not an array formula.
Will be set to the zero based lower row of the array formula currently being evaluated, or left unchanged if the formula currently being evaluated is not an array formula.
Will be set to the zero based right column of the array formula currently being evaluated, or left unchanged if the formula currently being evaluated is not an array formula.

member.name: M:SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.IArguments.GetArrayValue(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the specified value.
member.returns: The specified range or array value.
member.remarks: For single values, arguments.GetArrayValue(index, 0, 0) returns the same value as arguments[index].

example.code:
Imports System Imports SpreadsheetGear
Namespace ConsoleApplication _ '/ <summary> '/ Demonstrate a custom function which sums the range of cells or values passed to it. '/ </summary> Class Program
'Entry point which delegates to C-style main Private Function Public Overloads Shared Sub Main() ' Create a new empty workbook. Dim workbookSet As IWorkbookSet = Factory.GetWorkbookSet()
' Add the custom function to the workbook set. workbookSet.Add(MySum.MySumSingleton)
' Add a workbook to the workbook set. Dim workbook As IWorkbook = workbookSet.Workbooks.Add()
' Get the first sheet and it's cells Dim worksheet As SpreadsheetGear.IWorksheet = workbook.Worksheets(0) Dim cells As SpreadsheetGear.IRange = worksheet.Cells
' Assign values and formulas to cells. cells("A1").Value = 1 ' The OFFSET(...) function enables creation of a range equal to ' the number of rows which have values in column A and one column. cells("B1").Formula = "=MYSUM(OFFSET(A1,0,0,COUNT(A:A),1))"
Console.WriteLine(("Result calculated from MYSUM = " + cells("B1").Text + " (should be 1)."))
' Add another value to column A. cells("A2").Value = 2
Console.WriteLine(("Result calculated from MYSUM = " + cells("B1").Text + " (should be 3).")) End Sub 'Main End Class 'Program _
' A simple SUM custom function. Public Class MySum Inherits SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.Function ' Set to the one and only instance of MySum. Public Shared MySumSingleton As New MySum()
' Sum the numbers in a range or array. Public Overrides Sub Evaluate(ByVal arguments As SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.IArguments, ByVal result As SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.IValue) ' Verify that there are two arguments. If arguments.Count = 1 Then Dim rowCount As Integer Dim colCount As Integer arguments.GetArrayDimensions(0, rowCount, colCount) Dim numbers(rowCount, colCount) As Double Dim row As Integer For row = 0 To rowCount - 1 Dim col As Integer For col = 0 To colCount - 1 Dim value As SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.IValue = arguments.GetArrayValue(0, row, col) If value.Type = SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.ValueType.Number Then numbers(row, col) = value.Number End If Next col Next row ' Get the two arguments as numbers, and sum them. result.Number = SumThem(numbers) ' Return ValueError.Value. Else result.Error = SpreadsheetGear.ValueError.Value End If End Sub 'Evaluate
Private Function SumThem(ByVal numbers(,) As Double) As Double Dim sum As Double = 0.0 Dim rowCount As Integer = numbers.GetUpperBound(0) + 1 Dim colCount As Integer = numbers.GetUpperBound(1) + 1 Dim row As Integer For row = 0 To rowCount - 1 Dim col As Integer For col = 0 To colCount - 1 sum += numbers(row, col) Next col Next row Return sum End Function 'SumThem
' Singleton class - so make the constructor private. Private Sub New() ' The name of the custom function. MyBase.New("MYSUM", SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.Volatility.Invariant, SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.ValueType.Number) End Sub 'New ' For a given set of inputs, this function always returns the same value. End Class 'MySum End Namespace 'ConsoleApplication ' This function returns a number.

member.param: Specifies the zero based index of the argument.
Specifies the zero based row index of the value to get.
Specifies the zero based column index of the value to get.

member.name: M:SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.IArguments.GetLogical(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the argument specified by the zero based index as a logical (boolean) value. Note that this method has the side effect of converting a range or array to a single value.

remarks.para: Non-logical arguments are converted to a logical value if possible. Otherwise, false is returned by this method, and an internal flag is set indicating that an error has occurred, causing the result of the formula to be an error.
Note that this method has the side effect of converting a range or array to a single value. Use and to get the dimensions and values of a range or array.

member.name: M:SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.IArguments.GetNumber(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the argument specified by the zero based index as a double precision floating point number. Note that this method has the side effect of converting a range or array to a single value.

remarks.para: Non-numeric arguments are converted to a number if possible. Otherwise, 0.0 is returned by this method, and an internal flag is set indicating that an error has occurred, causing the result of the formula to be an error.
Note that this method has the side effect of converting a range or array to a single value. Use and to get the dimensions and values of a range or array.

member.name: M:SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.IArguments.GetText(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the argument specified by the zero based index as a string. Note that this method has the side effect of converting a range or array to a single value.

remarks.para: Non-text arguments are converted to text if possible. Otherwise, a zero length string is returned by this method, and an internal flag is set indicating that an error has occurred, causing the result of the formula to be an error.
Note that this method has the side effect of converting a range or array to a single value. Use and to get the dimensions and values of a range or array.

member.summary: Returns the argument specified by the zero based index. Note that this indexer has the side effect of converting a range or array to a single value.
member.remarks: Note that this indexer has the side effect of converting a range or array to a single value. Use and to get the dimensions and values of a range or array.

member.summary: Returns the number of arguments to the custom function.

member.summary: Returns the column of the cell which is currently being calculated.

member.name: P:SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.IArguments.CurrentFormula
member.summary: Returns the formula of the cell which is currently being evaluated, or null if no cell is currently being evaluated.
member.remarks: The formula will include a leading "=" and array formulas will be enclosed in curly braces - (i.e. "{=A1:B2}")).

member.name: P:SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.IArguments.CurrentRow
member.summary: Returns the row of the cell which is currently being calculated.

member.name: P:SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.IArguments.CurrentWorksheet
member.summary: Returns the worksheet of the cell which is currently being calculated. The Function.Evaluate method precludes the use of any API on this worksheet except for the Name, Index and Workbook.Name properties.

member.name: P:SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.IArguments.CurrentFunctionName
member.summary: Returns the name of the function which is currently being evaluated.
member.remarks: Use to determine the name of the function currently being evaluated. This is useful when implementing the default custom function (a function with a name of "*").

member.summary: Specifies the type of a value.

member.summary: Specifies that the type returned by a custom function is variable.

member.summary: Specifies an empty value.

member.name: F:SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.ValueType.Number
member.summary: Specifies a double precision floating point number.

member.name: F:SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.ValueType.Text
member.summary: Specifies text.

member.name: F:SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.ValueType.Logical
member.summary: Specifies a logical (boolean) value.

member.name: F:SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.ValueType.Error
member.summary: Specifies an error.

member.name: T:SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.Volatility
member.summary: Specifies the volatility of a custom function.
member.remarks: An example of VolatileEveryRecalc might be a custom function which returns a stock price. There is no guarantee that a VolatileEveryRecalc custom function will only be called once per recalc.

member.name: F:SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.Volatility.Invariant
member.summary: Specifies that a function always returns the same result for a given set of arguments.

member.name: F:SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.Volatility.VolatileEveryRecalc
member.summary: Specifies a volatile function which must be recalculated at least once every time the workbook set is recalculated or different arguments are passed to it.
member.remarks: An example of a VolatileEveryRecalc function would be a function which returns the current date. Such a function should be recalculated each time a workbook set is recalculated, however, multiple instances of the function with the same arguments may just be calculated once during the calculation of a workbook set. All cells containing volatile functions are marked as needing to be recalculated when any data is changed in a workbook set.

member.name: F:SpreadsheetGear.CustomFunctions.Volatility.VolatileEveryInstance
member.summary: Specifies a volatile function which must be recalculated for every instance.
member.remarks: An example of a VolatileEveryInstance function would be a random number generator, which should return a unique random number for every instance in every formula. Also, all cells containing volatile functions are marked as needing to be recalculated when any data is changed in a workbook set.

member.name: T:SpreadsheetGear.Charts.IChartGroup
member.summary: Represents options for one or more series of a chart.

remarks.para: Each chart has one or more chart groups. There is one chart group for each chart type (bar, line, area, etc...) which specifies options such as which axis to use for that chart type.
Each series of a chart is associated with exactly one chart group.

member.name: P:SpreadsheetGear.Charts.IChartGroup.Overlap
member.summary: Gets or sets the overlap or space between bars within a category as a percentage of the bar width.".

remarks.para: The value zero causes the bars to be placed adjacent to each other with no overlap or space between bars.
The positive value 100 causes bars to overlap completely.
The negative value -50 causes space equal to one half of the bar width between bars.

member.name: T:SpreadsheetGear.Themes.ColorSchemeIndex
member.summary: Specifies a color scheme index for getting and setting theme colors on fonts and fills as well as accessing theme colors with ITheme.ColorScheme[ColorSchemeIndex index].
member.remarks: The Excel 2007 API sometimes incorrectly swaps Dark1 and Light1 as well as Dark2 and Light2. The SpreadsheetGear API correctly treates Dark1 as "Text 1", Light1 as "Background 1", Dark2 as "Text 2" and Light2 as "Background 2".

member.name: F:SpreadsheetGear.Themes.ColorSchemeIndex.None
member.summary: Specifies that the represented color is not a theme color.

member.name: F:SpreadsheetGear.Themes.ColorSchemeIndex.Text1
member.summary: Specifies the "Text 1" theme color which is also referred to as "Dark1" and defaults to System.Drawing.SystemColors.WindowText in the default "Office" color scheme.

member.name: F:SpreadsheetGear.Themes.ColorSchemeIndex.Background1
member.summary: Specifies the "Background 1" theme color which is also referred to as "Light1" and defaults to System.Drawing.SystemColors.Window in the default "Office" color scheme.

member.name: F:SpreadsheetGear.Themes.ColorSchemeIndex.Text2
member.summary: Specifies the "Text 2" theme color which is also referred to as "Dark2" and defaults to dark blue in the default "Office" color scheme.

member.name: F:SpreadsheetGear.Themes.ColorSchemeIndex.Background2
member.summary: Specifies the "Background 2" theme color which is also referred to as "Light2" and defaults to tan in the default "Office" color scheme.

member.name: F:SpreadsheetGear.Themes.ColorSchemeIndex.Accent1
member.summary: Specifies the "Accent1" theme color which defaults to pale blue in the default "Office" color scheme.

member.name: F:SpreadsheetGear.Themes.ColorSchemeIndex.Accent2
member.summary: Specifies the "Accent2" theme color which defaults to pale red in the default "Office" color scheme.

member.summary: Specifies the "Accent3" theme color which defaults to pale olive green in the default "Office" color scheme.

member.summary: Specifies the "Accent4" theme color which defaults to pale purple in the default "Office" color scheme.

member.summary: Specifies the "Accent5" theme color which defaults to pale aqua in the default "Office" color scheme.

member.summary: Specifies the "Accent6" theme color which defaults to pale orange in the default "Office" color scheme.

member.name: T:SpreadsheetGear.PageBreakExtent
member.summary: Specifies the extent of a page break.
member.remarks: A full horizontal page break extends for all of the columns of a worksheet, whereas a partial horizontal page break is limited to a specific range of columns for the given row. Likewise, a partial vertical page break is limited to a specific range of rows for the given column.

member.summary: Specifies that a page break is a full vertical or horizontal page break.

member.name: F:SpreadsheetGear.PageBreakExtent.Partial
member.summary: Specifies that a page break is a partial vertical or horizontal page break.

member.summary: Text is centered across empty cells in the selection without merging the cells.

member.summary: Specifies that text should wrap and be aligned to form straight edges on the left and right, including the last line.
